I don’t need to knock on doors—desperation finds me. That day, a woman named Clara, her hair matted and her clothes frayed, stood outside a boarded-up laundromat, whispering to herself, clutching a child’s backpack.

She was new to the area, I could tell. Her eyes darted with the paranoia of someone who had just fallen through the cracks. I approached her with a smile, not the kind that invites, but the kind that says, *I see your weakness and I know how to use it.*

“Ma’am,” I said, leaning in just enough to make her feel cornered, “I heard you’re looking for a little help, are you not?”

She flinched, but nodded. I knew her story already. A medical emergency. A hospital bill that swallowed her savings. A job that vanished after a layoff. “Let’s not waste time with the banks,” I said. “They’ll just take your name and your hope. I can give you the money you need—$2,000 cash, right here, right now. All I ask is a little interest.”
